column2: Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday.	Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday.
column3: true

column2: When is it dated?
column3: When is it dated?

column2: But no matter; don't stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own.
column3: But no matter; don't stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own.

column2: Now, observe!
column3: Now, observe!

column2: I never doubted until within this hour or two, that he had, or could have such a paper.
column3: I never doubted until within this hour or two, that he had, or could have such a paper.

column2: It is good, until recalled.
column3: It is good, until recalled.

column2: But it may be soon recalled, and, I have reason to think, will be."
column3: But it may be soon recalled, and, I have reason to think, will be."

column2: They are not in danger?
column3: They are not in danger?

column2: They are in great danger.	They are in great danger.
column3: true

column2: They are in danger of denunciation by Madame Defarge.
column3: They are in danger of denunciation by Madame Defarge.

column2: I know it from her own lips.
column3: I know it from her own lips.

column2: I have overheard words of that woman's, to-night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours.
column3: I have overheard words of that woman's, to night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours.

column2: I have lost no time, and since then, I have seen the spy.
column3: I have lost no time, and since then, I have seen the spy.

column2: He confirms me.
column3: He confirms me.

column2: He knows that a wood-sawyer, living by the prison wall, is under the control of the Defarges, and has been rehearsed by Madame Defarge as to his having seen Her"--he never mentioned Lucie's name--"making signs and signals to prisoners.
column3: He knows that a wood sawyer, living by the prison wall, is under the control of the Defarges, and has been rehearsed by Madame Defarge as to his having seen Her"--he never mentioned Lucie's name-"making signs and signals to prisoners.

column2: It is easy to foresee that the pretence will be the common one, a prison plot, and that it will involve her life--and perhaps her child's--and perhaps her father's--for both have been seen with her at that place.
column3: It is easy to foresee that the pretence will be the common one, a prison plot, and that it will involve her life-and perhaps her child's-and perhaps her father's-for both have been seen with her at that place.

column2: Don't look so horrified.
column3: Don't look so horrified.

column2: You will save them all."
column3: You will save them all."

column2: Heaven grant I may, Carton!	Heaven grant I may, Carton!
column3: true

column2: But how?"
column3: But how?"

column2: I am going to tell you how.	I am going to tell you how.
column3: true

column2: It will depend on you, and it could depend on no better man.
column3: It will depend on you, and it could depend on no better man.

column2: This new denunciation will certainly not take place until after to-morrow; probably not until two or three days afterwards; more probably a week afterwards.
column3: This new denunciation will certainly not take place until after to morrow; probably not until two or three days afterwards; more probably a week afterwards.

column2: You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine.
column3: You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine.

column2: She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure.
column3: She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure.

column2: You follow me?"
column3: You follow me?"

column2: So attentively, and with so much confidence in what you say, that for the moment I lose sight, touching the back of the Doctor's chair, "even of this distress."
column3: So attentively, and with so much confidence in what you say, that for the moment I lose sight, touching the back of the Doctor's chair, "even of this distress."

column2: You have money, and can buy the means of travelling to the seacoast as quickly as the journey can be made.	You have money, and can buy the means of travelling to the seacoast as quickly as the journey can be made.
column3: true

column2: Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England.
column3: Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England.

column2: Early to-morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o'clock in the afternoon."
column3: Early to morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o'clock in the afternoon."

column2: It shall be done!
column3: It shall be done!

column2: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that Mr. Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.
column3: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that mr Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.

column2: You are a noble heart.	You are a noble heart.
column3: true

column2: Did I say we could depend upon no better man? Tell her, to-night, what you know of her danger as involving her child and her father.
column3: Did I say we could depend upon no better man? Tell her, to night, what you know of her danger as involving her child and her father.

column2: Dwell upon that, for she would lay her own fair head beside her husband's cheerfully." He faltered for an instant; then went on as before.
column3: Dwell upon that, for she would lay her own fair head beside her husband's cheerfully." He faltered for an instant; then went on as before.

column2: For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour.	For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour.
column3: true

column2: Tell her that it was her husband's last arrangement.
column3: Tell her that it was her husband's last arrangement.

column2: Tell her that more depends upon it than she dare believe, or hope.
column3: Tell her that more depends upon it than she dare believe, or hope.

column2: You think that her father, even in this sad state, will submit himself to her; do you not?"
column3: You think that her father, even in this sad state, will submit himself to her; do you not?"

column2: I am sure of it.
column3: I am sure of it.

column2: I thought so.	I thought so.
column3: true

column2: Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage. The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away."
column3: Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage. The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away."

column2: I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?
column3: I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?

column2: You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place.	You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place.
column3: true

column2: Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!"
column3: Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!"

column2: Why, then, said Mr. Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, "it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side."
column3: Why, then, said mr Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, "it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side."

column2: By the help of Heaven you shall!	By the help of Heaven you shall!
column3: true

column2: Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another."
column3: Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another."

column2: Nothing, Carton.
column3: Nothing, Carton.

column2: Remember these words to-morrow: change the course, or delay in it--for any reason--and no life can possibly be saved, and many lives must inevitably be sacrificed.
column3: Remember these words to morrow: change the course, or delay in it-for any reason-and no life can possibly be saved, and many lives must inevitably be sacrificed.

column2: I will remember them.	I will remember them.
column3: true

column2: I hope to do my part faithfully."
column3: I hope to do my part faithfully."

column2: And I hope to do mine.	And I hope to do mine.
column3: true

column2: Now, good bye!"
column3: Now, good bye!"

column2: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man's hand to his lips, he did not part from him then.
column3: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man's hand to his lips, he did not part from him then.

column2: He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have.
column3: He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have.

column2: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart--so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it--outwatched the awful night.
column3: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart-so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it-outwatched the awful night.

column2: He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of her room.
column3: He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of her room.

column2: Before he went away, he breathed a blessing towards it, and a Farewell.
column3: Before he went away, he breathed a blessing towards it, and a Farewell.
